reviewText:
There's two big reasons, two different types of people who play games. There are people who play video games to unwind, because they had a hard day at work and they want to let loose and not have to think, people who want to have fun without the worry of being stuck or presented with obstacles.

Then there are those who love punishment, people who live to play games like Journey to Silius, I Wanna Be The Guy or the more recent Dark Souls series. Diehards who don't want their hand held and want to be beaten mercilessly over and over until they finally learn what they've been doing wrong this whole time.

Shadowcrypt is absolutely a game for the latter, and I'm proud to say I'm one of these deranged masochists. This is a game that presents players with a big question; are you in touch with your roots?

As the torches of the title screen begin to flicker around the ominous skull decorating the entryway the haunting chants of the intro music beckon you to the dank and dark depths of the most brutal arcade platformer I've had the pleasure of playing.

Shadowcrypt is all about the combat. The bleak and claustrophobic level designs of the game only lend to your unbridled focus on the task at hand. All of your attention will be drawn to the beautifully crafted sprites and their precise animations as you slash and bash your way to the heart of the Crypts in pursuit of the wicked Necromancer.

Only 4 rooms into the game my mysterious cowled hero crumples to the floor dead..again..for the third time. I-I'll just try this again later.." I whimper to myself
date: tucking my gamepad away and walking away to make a sandwich to hopefully forget about this brutal game that just made me it's slave. Not even a minute later
recommended: I toss my condiments to the ground and declare "Eff that
hoursPlayed: I can do it!" and find myself rushing back to the computer where I give these beckoning crypts another go. I feel that same kind of determined spirit I held in the Famicom days.\n\nThe gameplay with it's visceral combat and the insane amount of concentration needed exceed my expectations
voteText: it's almost a little overwhelming. I've heard people call other games "the Dark Souls of 2D gaming" before many times in the past but Shadowcrypt is probably the first title I've played to actually match and truly capture the punishing and calculated approach to combat Dark Souls has
helpfulPercent: where every little move you make has a huge impact and consequence.\n\nEven more-so are the striking similarities to what seems to be the developer's hugest influence
votesTotal: from the candle finding objective needed to progress to the highly memorable and iconic shield-wielding Iron Knuckle battles that the combat here seems to inspire from heavily. It's the refreshing change of pace I've been waiting for since the golden-era of games.\n\nWhile I can see a lot of less patient players outright quitting in frustration the moment they die and are reduced to the starting 3-7dmg sword prior to a strong foe
votesFunny: the more retro-minded of players will remember this sort of challenge from our earlier and most important days of gaming. We'll stick with it and experience something exceedingly rewarding. You'll die often
commentsCount: but everytime you start again you'll feel better
column17: and make it a little bit further. And when you do finally beat those rooms? Holy crap
column18: it feels good.\n\nThough the system of losing your only reliable weapon will feel almost too brutal for newcomers
column19: it's what gives Shadowcrypt the refined gameplay it has. To give a sense of real distress in every confrontation and to make death that much more consequential.\n\nThe punishing nature is extremely familiar to the first Castlevania titles where dying would lose you your chained whip
column20: sticking you back with the puny leather alternative in the midst of a tough level. Konami in general were masters of this formula
column21: as my other favorite series Gradius was very similar in nature with deaths reverting you back to the almost useless pea-shooter.\n\nThat fear of losing what was making me do better in those classics caused a much higher level of awareness and addiction to the game. To succeed in Shadowcrypt you will need to adapt and get into the motions of the combat. You will block
column23: and bash your way through enemies
column24: you will learn to stand face-to-face with your most feared adversaries. Eventually
column25: things just start to 'click' with the player.\n\nThe game is certainly short and decidedly so. It requires a level of focus that if prolonged would just cause player fatigue on unmanageable levels. The short
column27: and very to-the-point approach gives a lot of breathing room for the hectic and chaotic nature of the player's progression.\n\nShadowcrypt is composed of one lengthy stage or "level" roughly the size of the original Castlevania
column28: but the amount of practice and dedication required in order to pass even a small section will have most players retrying for days before they're able to conquer nearly all of the evils within.\n\nYou will get no breaks nor will you receive any hand-holding

reviewText:
Would be a decent freeware game, but for what they are asking there simply isn't enough content to justify a purchase.

The 70+ non-linear rooms they boast is a downright lie. The game is very linear and a large majority of the rooms are copy-pasted.

All the weapons are identical apart from damage and a few enchantments they can have.

Get it for a dollar, otherwise I'd recommend getting something better.
voteText: 56 of 76 people (74%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
the game is very simplistic and linear. i would not recommend this to anyone unless they assign very little value to their dollar and want to play a difficult game that uses poor mechanics to accomplish its level of difficulty.

you must travel through the exact same dungeon each time you play. there is no random generation, there are no alternate routes, there are no interesting environments, there are no pacing mechanics. when you die you lose all your gear, meaning that upon your first death you will most likely save significant time by just ending your run immediately instead of trying to stab skeletons with the basic sword 30+ times in a row. there is a significant amount of mandatory backtracking through empty rooms each time you play the game. approximately 40% of your time spent on a run will consist of walking back through a long series of already cleared rooms.

the combat gives you very little to work with: jumping can potentially provide you with an extra attack due to frame reset upon landing, but makes you very vulnerable. ducking makes you stationary, resulting in it being a worthless mechanic. enemies don't follow the rules of the game: they ignore damage from traps, and in addition to attacking you will also harm you upon contact while constantly walking forwards. this means that all forms of normal" combat (ducking
recommended: parrying) are thrown out the window since you can not backstep their approach during all of these maneuvers. instead
hoursPlayed:
you must backstep-stab-repeat ad nauseam in order to guarantee defeating an enemy safely.

there is very little content. every sword is identical in usage except for the randomly varying damage ranges and the possibility for 1 of 3 elemental enchants that have a 10% chance (RNG? in a game where "quick reflex and timing are key"?) to trigger a minor effect. there are also 3 shields in the game with chances to trigger minor bonuses. that is all of the "gear" in the game.

you will quickly grow tired of going through the exact same basic rooms time and time again
voteText: fighting the same limited collection of simple enemies."
votesFunny: 54 of 82 people (66%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The mechanics are simple, the gameplay is even simpler. There's a subtle beauty to the game but whether or not it's worth $10 is questionable.

It's a great way to waste an afternoon but it relies heavily on the nostalgia that many indie-pixel games do, expecting players to find their own fun in a rather simplistic game is a tough call. Each room is similar, often too similar or out-right copied, flipped and filled with different enemies making it difficult to really discern where the player is going, a problem that's exacerbated by the slow movement in the game. Combat is also a slow dredge but very rewarding as each enemy has the capability to kill the player who in turn must rely on quick thinking and a few simple moves to over come a single or multiple enemies. Puzzle rooms are cleverly designed with a few simple pieces working together to create a real challenge, and the timer is a unobstructive and positive addition for potential speed-runners.

If $10 isn't a huge price tag to you, the it's a good game. Else, wait for it to go on sale.

reviewText:
Shadowcrypt is niche to say the least. So 8-bit at its core that it takes either a very old person or someone with an aquired taste for oldschool gamedesign to really appreciate the perfect simplicity of it.

Here is the deal: fight through a bunch of rooms and corridors and kick some evil necromancer in the skull. Basically, it is a sword & sorcerey short story turned game. The game itself is about the same level as first and second generation NES titles in terms of complexity. Possible actions include: attacking, jumping, shield-bashing, hanging on ledges and spear-throwing. You use this to overcome a clone-army of undead skeleton warriors and wizards, spike pits and pointy sticks on the ceiling.

Sounds rather sparse, right? It sure is, but being so limited also makes the game feel pretty on point" in delivering that oldschool flavor that I still crave today
date: 20 years after these kind of games were dying out. You see
recommended: most games today seem to cram everything and then some into their gameplay - so much that they feel overwhelming and I end up growing tired of a game that only does everything and tries to please as many types of gamers as possible. Shadowcrypt on the other hand has super-limited scope (survive till the end
hoursPlayed: kill necromancer) and the few mechanics implemented in this game feel natural and fitting for the task at hand (basically

reviewText:
not what i expected at all.. the combat gets really boring real quick, and i didn't even like it to begin with.
i expected something more Link on NES -like but instead the enemies continue walking towards you to the point that they walk right into you instead of stopping and fighting, making everything even more annoying.
i get that the dev went for a bit harder combat, and i love hardcore 2D platformers where volgarr's one example of a hardcore old school platformer done right, but the difficulty in shadowcrypt just feels cheap as hell and the way you have to play the game just isn't enjoyable at all.

i even took up these issues and more with the dev who basically told me that this is his vision of the game even though i said that the number of people who'll actually enjoy this game is minimal.
well.. i hope you enjoy your vision mr dev now when no one else is.

i thought it looked really kool but got this crap instead.. what annoys me the most is the missed potential here. with some fine-tuning and adding something more to the gameplay than running through catacombs" for fun with no real incentive.

reviewText: Simply put, this game is great and the negative reivews do not have much merrit. For example, one of them complains about backtracking, which was not only a minor part of the game, but is also very easy since the enemies remain dead. Is it overpriced for what it is? Sure. When I sat down seriously with the intent to beat it, I completed the game in 40 minutes. $10 seems a bit much for that, but it was a good time. The controls are simple, and they are tight. If you died, it's completely your fault. There isn't much healing, so you need to be on point. It is hard, but fair, and if you don't like that type of game, *that's fine*, but that doesn't make it a bad game.\n\nReally, the price for the amount of content is the only valid complaint. The game can be grueling and stressful, and this is completely intentional. It feels like Dark Souls when you're out of Estus and have no idea how far away the next bonfire is. Thumbs up from me: I want more.
voteText: 9 of 10 people (90%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Excellent game for anyone looking for a game that's simple but challenging.

Shadowcrypt feels very retro in all the best ways: Simple controls, a manual with valuable game knowledge, no long tutorial, and the best part: its replay value comes from not the length of the game or a plethura of features and modes, but the sheer challenge of finishing the game (and getting achievements).

To clear things up:

This is a combat-based platformer, meaning that if you don't learn the timing and dynamics of the combat, you won't get very far. Understanding that this is by design and is meant to be adapted to is essential to enjoying and completing Shadowcrypt.

The description may sound like the game has procedurally generated levels, but it does not. This isn't a bad thing though, once you get into the game you learn to embrace it. The levels are technically non-linear, but at the end of the day, they're linear. They just involve exploration and remembering where to go; the crypt is confusing and a bit maze-like, but that's a part of the game. Getting lost in the crypt is also part of the game. You'll see.

You get three lives, and when you lose them all you start over from the beginning. A complaint I hear a lot is people saying once you lose your first life you're screwed because you lose all of your gear (which is an important part to progressing). To these people I say: Don't get discouraged! You can beat this game with the starting crappy weapons, as impossible as that may sound. If you're good at fighting in this combat-based game, you will move forward. And there will most likely be a weapon or shield drop or a treasure chest. Just keep going, don't give up!

Final verdict:

This is one of the BEST games I've played this year. It took me a long time to beat it and I appreciated the mood, the music, the excellent character animation, the sound of the dungeon doors opening and closing, and especially the challenge. It's old school and feels like you picked it up from the SNES bin at the local game store, and I love that.

I'd love to see another game like this from One-bit Punch, or a sequel. I'd love to see more weapons, more levels, and more boss fights. I couldn't tell you how much money I'd pay for another, longer, more expansive version of this exact game.

It's grindy, it's retro, it's moody, it's a real challenge. I'll be playing it more in attempts to get the ridiculously challenging achievements. I highly recommend this game. 10/10

reviewText:
일자형 진행 방식의 액션 로그라이크 게임입니다.
레벨은 오로지 1개만 존재하고, 방 안의 적들을 모두 물리쳐야 다음 방으로 들어가는 게이트가 열립니다.
레벨 맵 구조는 동일합니다. 변화가 없습니다. 지도같은 것도 존재하지 않아서 그냥 여러번 플레이하면 자동으로 외워집니다.
굳이 여러번 플레이할 필요는 없지만, 도전과제를 보면 마음이 바뀌게 됩니다.

도전과제 (Achievements)
- 한 번도 죽지 않고 클리어하기.
- 한 번도 죽지 않고 한 대도 맞지 않고 클리어하기.
- 100번 죽기.
- 30분 내로 클리어하기.
- 방패로 100번 막기.
- 보스방 소환 해골 400마리 죽이기.

이 밖에도 어려운 도전과제들이 많습니다.

도전과제에 얽매이지 않는 유저라면 한 번 클리어하고 나서 다시 할 필요는 없습니다.
그렇지만 플레이 타임도 짧고 난이도도 약간 높아서 보스방까지 갈 수 있을 정도로 게임에 적응하는 시간이 좀 걸립니다.
그렇게까지 적응이 된 다음 게임을 최초로 클리어하고 나면, 자연스레 아쉬움이 남으면서 좀더 하드하게 갈 마음이 생길 겁니다.
적어도 저는 그렇네요...


개인적으로 아쉬운 점은 즐길만한 요소가 너무 적다는 것입니다.
하나밖에 없는 레벨, 동일한 맵 구조, 너무 적은 아이템과 몬스터 유형...
일반적인 유저들은 오로지 도전과제 하나 때문에 계속 플레이하지는 않습니다.
좀 더 다양한 무언가가 있었다면 괜찮았을텐데...

reviewText:
Fun game, but it lacks content and it can be VERY frustrating. I bought this on 50% sale for 5 euros, and I must say the game is fun and addicting. The game is all about combat which is nice, however this combat is almost the same all the way through. Also there is no tutorial for the combat system, so you will probably end up dying a lot of times to your first encounter with a sword/spear.

The game also lacks content. It is the same dungeon every time and the items are almost the same. Even the achivement system is poor in my opinion. The game is fun though and the artstyle is just amazing.

In short: The game lacks content. The game is probably worth 5 euros, but over that is just not worth your money in my opinion.
voteText: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Shadowcrypt is a semi-challening combat focused platformer that takes obvious influence from classics like Castelvania and Zelda.  Unfortunately it is missing a few things that would make me recommend it.  The lack of content for the price is the biggest issue here and if the game was a quarter of the price then I would perhaps look at the game differently.

Like arcade games of old, death will put you back to the beginning of the game.  The dungeon is not procedurely generated, so death will mean you will be playing through the same dungeon over and over.  This isn't a problem if the level you are forced to repeat is enjoyable.  Unfortunately in Shadowcrypt, many rooms are empty and encounters are separated through backtracking which becomes tedious very quickly.  Most of my playtime was spent jumping through empty rooms that look almost identical.  More encounters and some new designs to make areas fresh would have worked wonders.

Combat is quite enjoyable, certain enemies require patience and if you try to hack and slash your way through everything then you will most likely die.  Again though, lack of content means that the combat isn't as good as it could have been.  Swords and shields are great, but to limit combat to only these weapons with some slight variations based on damage is just poor.  I would have loved a staff with limited usage or a slow and heavy battle axe to crush certain enemies under their shields.  The lack of content just pops up time and time again.

Repetitive encounters, environments and a focus on backtracking just make Shadowcrypt more of a chore than it should be.  At the moment it is too expensive for the content and you will be able to find much more enjoyable experiences for less money.  If you are a fan of classic arcade platformers then maybe put this one in your wishlist and wait for a massive sale.

reviewText:
If you prefer games that hold your hand as it walks you through the steps to beating it, this game is not for you. Shadowcrypt is brutal and unforgiving romp through a dungeon filled with enemies that are all capable of easily wasting your hero if you think you can just hack and slash your way through them.

The game doesn't ask much from the player in terms of platforming or exploration, but can be taxing in the combat department. knowing when to block and when to strike can be crutial, and being able to block a standing or crouching attack can be the difference between life and death to your hero.

The basic level asthetic might be enough to turn some players away, but it only furthers to highlight what this game seems to center around; the combat.

reviewText:
This game feels a lot like the old Prince of Persia 2D games, but not nearly as tight. It has potential, but as it stands, I don't think I'd recommend to anyone.

The combat is supposed to be tight and unforgiving, but without a dodge-roll/active block, you're pretty much stuck doing hit & run/shield bashing tactics. Enemies can take upwards of 20 hits each, and are bound to hit you a few times in between, taking off precious health, which is almost impossible to replenish.

You have 3 lives to beat the entire game. Lose em, start over from scratch. Also, whenever you die, you lose all of your upgrades/pickups. It kinda sucks, especially later on.

The animations & visuals are pretty decent, and I'd have loved to see more out of this game, but it feels like the potential here is wasted a little.

Overall, the game isn't that fun, and without a serious overhaul of the combat, probably never will be.

http://youtu.be/9YsL0XDXWrY

reviewText:
I bought this game simply for the combat system. It looked precise, fast, and not too complicated. I was not dissapointed. Everything in this game is very precise; jumping, attacking, ducking, and bashing. To put it simply, this is very much a game where you will only die if it is your fault. So far the game has been very fair, but still difficult.

This game is not randomly generated rooms. It does not advertise randomly generated rooms. Every playthrough will have the same rooms with the same enemy and trap placement. The only thing random about this game is the item drops and on-hit modifiers. Some people might want randomly generated rooms (and it is appealing to subsequent playthroughs for some games) but this game is in the mindset of Legend of Zelda II, Castlevania, and classic arcade games. Every encounter is carefully crafted, not generated.

The combat is precise, simple, satisfying, and difficult but fair. When you are not moving or attacking, your shield automatically blocks hits. Enemies can do damage to you with attacks or by walking into you. If enemies didn't deal damage from walking into you the game would be very easy. Some enemies have no good way to counter you if you just duck and stab. Ducking doesn't let you shield bash, but dodges high attacks and blocks low ones, making you extremely defensive. If they couldn't walk into you to deal damage, every encounter would end with you ducking and stabbing their ankles to death while taking no damage. Doing hit and run tactics by constantly running and stabbing is sort of viable, but not nearly as fast, satisfying, or viable as just keeping enemies back with a shield bash. It's the superior tactic. The javelins help in terms of dealing damage from a range, but you have a limited supply and they don't deal a lot of damage. Attacks and shield bashes hit all enemies in front of you which helps make groups manageable, though so far I haven't had more than two people attack me at once. Again, if you take damage in combat, you only have yourself to blame.

This game does not advertise itself as an RPG or a rogue-like. It is very much an action game, and a very tactical, precise one.

The atmosphere is nice, but nothing special. You trek through a fairly standard dungeon with nice pixel graphics and a fitting soundtrack. It's decent, but nothing to scream about. The pixel lighting is very nice though and adds a whole lot, though.

EDIT:
Simply playing the game for a bit longer showed me what each element and shield does. Fire for damage, ice for stun, and lightning for knockback and piercing javelins. Defender has a chance to stun, Avenger for damage, and Hammer for extra knockback. It is a fairly short game, but a fun one that I can see myself replaying a lot. The only thing that takes away from this game is it's relatively short length and everything that comes along with that. The story is minimal, but not really important in this type of game. If this game was ever expanded or used as a basis for another game, I would like to see pretty much more of everything. More kinds of enemies, more traps, more weapons, more elements, more shields, more rooms, and more areas. The number of these things in Shadowcrypt itself suffices for its scope, but there really is only room for improvement.
voteText: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Love it. Very atmospheric and skill dependant. Honestly, for the asking price, it's a tough sell: little variety, extremely short, and few features. However, there's no doubt that the game is fun and well made. The action-rpg elements are a nice touch and the achievements are great to go through. Buy if you're into skill games or games with character. I love that the enemies are random in their attacks. That makes the combat fresh every time for me. I hope there's a sequel that fixes the only issue with this installment: it needs more stuff! Cool music and graphics too.

reviewText: If it's discounted then try it. 10€ may be too much for this title. Yet it gave me some nice moments and I play it casually. The combat system is very good and slaying enemies is enjoyable. The level design could be more varied. Seeing the same corridors and chambers for all the time could get you bored. Also a random chamber generator could extent fun and give lot's of replayability. It's a tough title. If you are stubborn then try to finish it.

reviewText:
I agree with people saying it's too expensive. I played it a little before getting a refund for it.

I like the difficulty and the general idea of the game, but the advertised non-linearity, as said in other reviews, just leads to lots of running around aimlessly. Which is even more awful given the repetitive design. It's not like you're aimlessly wandering around through beatiful and unique landscapes. Which makes it even harder to remember which door you took last time and which you have not tried yet.

The combat is ok. I really hate it, though, when I am locked into an animation in a game where very quick reaction times are asked of the user. If I cannot attack because I might have to block an enemy attack which may or may not come, all the while the enemy moving in on you (which is bad because you lose health if an enemy runs into you without even attacking) makes for some really frustrating experiences.

Then there is the absolute randomness of drops that may make the game really easy or really hard, purely depending on your dropluck. You can get a 12dmg sword off the very first super easy enemy and then breeze through the game for quite a while or be stuck with your starting sword, finding it almost impossible to beat harder enemies who have absurd amounts of health. Which also ties in with the terrible decision to make you lose any swords/shields you have picked up when you die, basically dooming you.
Item drops should get progressively stronger as you progress through the game and you really should not lose the items you gathered when you die. That's just a super bad design move as it leaves you with barely any damage on enemies with extremely high health later in the game.

I may pick it up again when it's a lot cheaper than the 5€ I got it for on the sale, but I'd really appreciate some changes to the game to make it a little more friendly. The game is hard enough through the combat patterns and limited lives. You don't have to ♥♥♥♥ people over even harder by stripping them off their gear on death and way too slow attack/shield bash animations.

reviewText:
A simplistic and annoyingly tedius game that is difficult in all the wrong ways.

A lot of backtracking means that you'll have to slowly walk through the same rooms you have cleared just to continue on. Speaking of slow moving, your character barely has a brisk walk going on which draws this game out.

Characters are overpowered for just being skeletons, and the game repeatedly gives you items you do not need.

When you die, you start with basic equipment, meaning you'll be stabbing an enemy over 30 times just to kill it. Shields aren't explained as far as their abilities go, and the repetative enviroment dulls the entire experience, not to mention the lackluster music and sound design.

Save yourself some money and skip on this poor excuse of a platformer. It's callback to Zelda II and Castlevania is undeserved.
voteText: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Random drops but designed levels leaves me a little uneasy, especially due to the difficulty. Your ability to progress is at least somewhat tied to what drops you're lucky enough to get. And then when you ultimately die (which will happen a few times, the game isn't straight up pick up and play), you have to trudge through the exact same corridors.

That aside, the game has great atmosphere, and the combat is quite rewarding, in a similar way to Dark Souls. Perhaps the enemies could telegraph their attacks a little bit more, but if you mess up it's usually the player's fault (except that their power is tied to the RNG gods).

Luckily the game is quite short, so it's not as if you'll lose hours of progress upon death. While not perfect, fans of prince of persia, dark souls, metroid or legend of zelda 2 might find something to enjoy here.
voteText: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is punishing. It's like standing on trying to reach a nice bowl of ice cream at the other end of a room that has lego scattered all over the floor and you left your shoes in some highly inconvenient place. The only difference is that I'm entirely sure what flavour of ice cream is at the other end, if there even is any ice cream there. I'm endangering my poor little feet purely for the hope of ice cream that might not even exist.

This game is ♥♥♥♥ing punishing. It's difficult for the sake of being difficult in an attempt to be a throwback to the years of the NES. However, is the pain you're putting yourself through really worth it? That's hard to say.

Shadowcrypt is stupidly difficult but also rather addictive, if you enjoy a challenge. You'll get a few rooms in and die on your last life, so close to the door that could very well be the last room in the game. I haven't finished it (I played mostly on the exe before realising I had a Steam key), but I keep coming back for more, hoping to strike lucky and get to the end. The problem is that while there is skill involved to beating it, there's also a desperate need for luck. Swords and health drops are rare and I pity the poor soul who's sat next to me whenever I end up getting spears instead, which seem mostly useless bar the odd situation or two.

This game is punishing and it's difficult to recommend as it does feel pretty unfair to play at times. The enemies take way too many hits; too few wouldn't make for much of a challenge, and the high health certainly does create challenge, but it feels very artificial. I think that maybe enemy health has been nerfed on the steam version in comparison to the exe version I played, but it stills seems a little too high to feel comfortable with.

Regardless, I would recommend this to fans of Dark Souls and other ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s who enjoy a challenge. It was fun to pass this around to my friends and see who could get the furthest, but it loses its appeal when you die for the 500th time by being knocked off a tiny ledge by an archer whilst dodging pike traps. I'm sorry, I'm having Anor Londo flashbacks...

reviewText:
Absolutely terrible game. Mechanics are simplistic and lack depth. Combat is half-decent with enemies having low, high, and overhead attacks. Graphics are serviceable, with decent animations and have an appealing look to them. Outside of that, the game has little redeeming value.

The environment is repetitive and not randomized. Backtracking and looking for keys is a pain, especially since your character's walk speed is incredibly slow. Weapon variety is practically non-existent, with just the sword getting slightly stronger or gaining insignificant elemental attributes.

All in all, quite possibly the worst purchase I've ever made on Steam.
